Dr. Harry Lyle. Director, Massachusetts Board of Educational Television, Boston
111 represent the Massachusetts Board of Educational Television, along with Miss
Elizabeth McConarty of North Quincy High School. The Board was established in
June, 1953, and set up basically to furnish educational and cultural television
programs for commercial and non-commercial television stations in the Commonwealth.
We are charged with the responsibility of acting for the Commonwealth in matters
pertaining to educational television.”
Dr, Constance WarrenT former President. Sarah Lawrence College, New York:
only excuse for being here at this family gathering is my interest in the
possibilities of ETV as an excellent medium for education. Since I’m not a repre¬
sentative, shall I speak for the Tri-State area of Maine, Vermont and New Hampshire?
New Hampshire is the most interested of the three and so far, Mr. Ted Kingsbury of
Kenne has been the most active. For some time, Maine had difficulty, since their
Governor wasn’t particularly interested in the field, but now with the new Governor,
and after a conference last year with 36 interested groups attending, Maine has a
committee of 15 working on the problem. There was some talk of getting a trans¬
mitter for ETV on Mt. Washington, but the people were so slow at moving on the
project, that Canada moved a channel even closer than it was and blocked out the
possibility of using Channel 11 on Mt. Washington. It looks now as if New
Hampshire and Vermont will go to Mb. Kearsarge and leave out Maine, so Maine will
have to set up a station of its own in connection with the University. Yet there
will still be some degree of cooperation, as I hope there will be with our
neighbor, Massachusetts. ETV is very important in these states - especially in
the rural areas.”
